title: RL32782
content: In February 2002, the Bush Administration proposed "Clear Skies" to address emissions of sulfur dioxide, nitrogen oxides, mercury, and carbon dioxide. The proposal aimed to amend the Clean Air Act by implementing emission caps on electric utility emissions through a tradeable allowance program. Introduced in the 108th Congress as H.R. 999 and S. 485, a modified version (S. 131) was introduced in the 109th Congress by Senator Inhofe. Debate has focused on the cap-and-trade implementation scheme. In the 109th Congress, a modified version of Clear Skies (S. 131) has been introduced by Senator Inhofe and is the focus of congressional hearings. The debate surrounding the Administration's Clear Skies proposal has centered on its cap-and-trade implementation scheme, which aims to deliver guaranteed emissions reductions of SO2, NOx, and mercury at a fraction of command and control costs. EPA has already used a regional cap-and-trade program to control NOx emissions over the eastern United States under existing Clean Air Act authority. The proposal's cap-and-trade provisions are less significant in terms of the Clean Air Act. EPA has already used a regional cap-and-trade program to control NOx emissions. The Clear Skies legislation aims to simplify regulations by combining various aspects of the Clean Air Act into one streamlined process for utilities. This would potentially eliminate the need for New Source Review, regional haze, BART, MACT standards, NOx SIP Call, 126 Rule, and acid rain regulations.
